The intracellular segments of the α1 subunit, viz. the N and C termini and the intracellular loops between domains I and II, II and III, and III and IV, possess the binding/recognition sites for second messengers such as G-protein βγ subunits or intracellular Ca2+ ([Ca2+]i) as well as sites that can be phosphorylated by protein kinase C (PKC) 1The abbreviations used are: PKC, protein kinase C; cPKC, classic PKC; nPKC, novel PKC; PMA, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate; MCh, acetyl-β-methylcholine; DAG, diacylglycerol; WT, wild type. (5Stea A. Soong T.W. Snutch T.P. Neuron. 1995; 15: 929-940Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar, 6Hamid J. Nelson D. Spaetgens R. Dubel S. Snutch T. Zamponi G. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6195-6202Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar, 7Melliti K. Meza U. Adams B. J. Neurosci. 2000; 20: 7167-7173Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 8Zuhlke R. Reuter H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 3287-3294Crossref PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar). PKC isozymes can be divided into three classes based on their requirement for the cofactors. The classic PKCs (cPKCs; α, βI, βII, and γ) require calcium and are stimulated by phosphatidylserine and diacylglycerol (DAG). Novel PKCs (nPKCs; δ, ε, η, and θ) are calcium-independent but still stimulated by phosphatidylserine and DAG. Members of the third category, atypical PKCs (ξ and λ/ι), are Ca2+- and DAG-independent. PKC activation by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA) enhanced Cav 2.2 or 2.3 currents, whereas Cav 1.2c (from rat brain) or 2.1 currents were not affected (1Kamatchi G. Franke R. Lynch III, C. Sando J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4102-4109Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 5Stea A. Soong T.W. Snutch T.P. Neuron. 1995; 15: 929-940Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar, 6Hamid J. Nelson D. Spaetgens R. Dubel S. Snutch T. Zamponi G. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6195-6202Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar, 7Melliti K. Meza U. Adams B. J. Neurosci. 2000; 20: 7167-7173Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Kamatchi G. Tiwari S. Chan C. Chen D. Do S.-H. Durieux M. Lynch III, C. Brain Res. 2003; 968: 227-237Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). In contrast, acetyl-β-methylcholine (MCh), another activator of PKC, potentiated Cav 2.3 currents, decreased Cav 1.2c currents, and failed to modulate Cav 2.1 or 2.2 currents (1Kamatchi G. Franke R. Lynch III, C. Sando J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4102-4109Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). The differential responses of the Cav currents to the PKC activators may be attributed to the presence of PKC isozyme-selective phosphorylation sites in the α1 subunit of the Cav channels. In a recent study (9Kamatchi G. Tiwari S. Chan C. Chen D. Do S.-H. Durieux M. Lynch III, C. Brain Res. 2003; 968: 227-237Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar), we suggested that cPKCs were responsible for the potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents by 1 μm MCh (EC50), the M1 receptor agonist. In contrast, nPKCs were implicated in PMA-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents (9Kamatchi G. Tiwari S. Chan C. Chen D. Do S.-H. Durieux M. Lynch III, C. Brain Res. 2003; 968: 227-237Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). The above findings led us to hypothesize the existence of PMA-selective and MCh-selective potential PKC phosphorylation sites in the α1 2.3 subunits. The MCh-selective sites (Ser-888, Ser-892, Ser-894, and Ser-1987) are unique to the α1 2.3 subunits, whereas the PMA-selective sites (Thr-365, Ser-369, Thr-879, Ser-1995, and Ser-2011) are homologous to α1 2.2 subunits. In our previous study, we showed that Ala mutation of the MCh-selective Ser sites inhibited MCh-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents while leaving the PMA response intact (1Kamatchi G. Franke R. Lynch III, C. Sando J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4102-4109Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). As a follow-up, the specificity of PMA-selective sites to PMA was investigated in the current study. Putative PMA-selective potential PKC phosphorylation sites of α1 2.3 subunits were mutated to Ala, and the mutants were coexpressed with M1 receptors in Xenopus oocytes. Contrary to expectations, Ser/Thr → Ala mutation of the sites predicted to be PMA-selective inhibited both PMA- and MCh-induced enhancement of Cav 2.3 currents. The MCh response seems to require the sites necessary for the PMA response in addition to the previously identified MCh-specific sites. Construction of Mutants—Selected Ser/Thr were mutated to Ala by primer extension employing PCR with PfuTurbo DNA polymerase (QuikChange XL site-directed mutagenesis kit, Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). Wild type rat brain α1 2.3 subunit subcloned in the pMT vector was used as the template. The PCR product was treated with DpnI, a restriction enzyme specific for methylated and hemimethylated DNA, to digest the template DNA. The digested PCR product was transformed in Escherichia coli using the protocol from the supplier, and the DNA from the selected transformants was processed for sequencing. The whole coding region of the construct was sequenced (Biomolecular Research Facility, University of Virginia) to confirm the planned mutation and the absence of unwanted mutations contributed by the PCR reaction. Harvesting of Oocytes and cDNA Injection—Mature female Xenopus laevis frogs were obtained from Xenopus I (Ann Arbor, MI), housed in an established frog colony, and fed regular frog brittle on alternate days. For the removal of oocytes, a frog was anesthetized in 500 ml of 0.2% 3-aminobenzoic acid ethyl ester (Sigma) in water until unresponsive to a painful stimulus. The anesthetized frog was placed supine on ice, and an incision of ~1.5 cm in length was made through both the skin and muscle layers of one lower abdominal quadrant. A section of the ovary was exteriorized, and a lobule of oocytes (~500) was removed. The wound was closed in two layers, and the animal was allowed to recover from anesthesia, kept in a separate tank overnight, and returned to the colony the following day. The oocytes were washed twice in a calcium-free OR2 solution (in mm: NaCl 82.5, KCl 2, MgCl2 1.8, HEPES 5, pH 7.5) and transferred to OR2 solution containing 1 mg/ml collagenase (type 1A; Sigma). The dish containing the oocytes in collagenase solution was agitated for a period of 2–3 h at room temperature to remove the follicular cell layer. Defolliculation was confirmed by microscopic examination. Then the oocytes were washed in OR2 solution and transferred to modified Barth's solution (in mm: NaCl 88, KCl 1, NaHCO3 2.4, CaCl2 0.41, MgSO4 0.82, HEPES 15, pH 7.4) containing 2.5 mm sodium pyruvate and 10 μg/ml gentamycin sulfate. The oocytes were allowed to recover by incubation at 16 °C for 3–10 h before cDNA injection. Nuclear (germinal vesicle) injection was performed (Drummond “Nanoject,” Drummond Scientific Co., Broomall, PA) using a maximum of 4 ng of cDNA containing 3 ng of a 1:1:1 mix (molar ratio) of Cav α1 2.3, β1B, α2/δ cDNA subunits and 1 ng of rat M1 receptor cDNA in pcDNA 3.1 (Invitrogen). The oocytes were returned to Barth's solution and incubated at 16 °C for 6–8 days before the recording of current. Current Recording—Macroscopic currents with Ba2+ (IBa) as the charge carrier were recorded employing a two-electrode voltage clamp technique using Oocyte Clamp OC-725C (Warner Instrument Corp., Hamden, CT). The amplifier was linked to an interface and an IBM PC-compatible computer equipped with pClamp software (version 8.2; Axon Instruments, Foster City, CA) for data acquisition and analysis. Leak currents were subtracted using the P/4 procedure. Microelectrodes with an agarose cushion were filled with 3 m CsCl; typical resistances were 0.5–2.5 megohms. KCl-agar bridges were used as ground electrodes to minimize any junction potential attributable to changes in ionic composition of the bath solution. The oocytes were placed in a recording chamber (~500-μl volume) and superfused with the recording solution containing (in mm): Ba(OH)2 40, NaOH 50, KOH 2, HEPES 5, using methanesulfonate as the anion to adjust the pH to 7.4. Niflumic acid (0.4 mm) was included to block intrinsic chloride channels. Oocytes were held at –80 mV before being depolarized 0 mV, the test potential for a duration of 850 ms. The current-voltage (I-V) relationship of oocytes expressing the wild type Cav 2.3 channel or the mutant was determined wherever necessary. I-V was recorded for a duration of 450 ms using step depolarizations from –50 to 100 mV in 10-mV increments. Drug Treatment—All of the oocytes exhibiting IBa greater than 400 nA underwent control, treatment, and wash protocols. The control IBa was recorded at 8 min after the oocyte was impaled. Following the recording of the control IBa, either PMA or MCh was perfused for 60 s, and the current was recorded after another 60 s, thus exposing the oocyte to the agonist for a period of 2 min. Chemicals—PMA (Calbiochem) and MCh (Sigma) were dissolved in Me2SO (0.05%) and distilled water, respectively. The concentrated stock solutions of MCh and PMA were stored frozen at –20 °C. These agents were diluted to their final concentration in recording solution on the day of the experiment. To block endogenous Cl– currents, niflumic acid (Sigma) was added to the recording solution, which was stirred overnight in order for it to dissolve. Data Analysis—The data are shown as means ± S.E. unless otherwise indicated. The peak IBa represented the maximum amplitude of the inward current. The current inactivation rate was fit by a single exponential function using the equation, y=A×exp(−t/τ)+R(Eq. 1) where A is the coefficient of the exponential, t is time (ms), τ is the time constant (ms), and R is the fraction of residual current. Statistical significance was determined using the t test, and p < 0.05 was considered significant. Selection of Potential PKC Phosphorylation Sites—The strategy employed for the selection of potential PKC phosphorylation sites from the α1 subunits of Cav channels was described in detail previously (1Kamatchi G. Franke R. Lynch III, C. Sando J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4102-4109Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). Briefly, the sites were chosen based on the existence of a linear and/or helical motif for PKC recognition and sequence differences between the various α1 subunits. These potential PKC phosphorylation sites were chosen from the intracellular regions (a total of 13 regions) only, as they could be expected to have access to PKC. A set of four unique MCh-selective sites (Ser-888, Ser-892, Ser-894, and Ser-1987) and five putative PMA-selective sites (Thr-365, Ser-369, Thr-879, Ser-1995, and Ser-2011) was identified in the α1 2.3 subunit (Fig. 1). The PMA-selective sites in the α1 2.3 subunit are homologous to those in the α1 2.2 subunit. Ser/Thr → Ala Substitution of the Predicted PMA-selective Sites Inhibit PMA-induced Potentiation of Peak Cav 2.3 Currents—A quintuple Ser/Thr → Ala mutation of the predicted PMA sites was constructed as a first step toward examining our prediction. Expressed IBa through the Cav 2.3 channel quintuple mutant, T365A/S369A/T879A/S1995A/S2011A, or the Cav 2.3 WT channel were studied and analyzed in parallel. The IBa peaked between –10 and 20 mV in both the wild type and the quintuple mutant. The peak current amplitude was observed at 75.8 ± 0.3 ms (mean ± S.E., n = 28) and 76 ± 0.3 ms (mean ± S.E., n = 23) in the WT and the quintuple mutant, respectively. Analysis of the I-V plot revealed that the IBa appeared at –40 mV and reversed between 70 and 90 mV in both the wild type and the quintuple mutant. The kinetic properties of the currents from the oocytes expressing the quintuple mutant, T365A/S369A/T879A/S1995A/S2011A, were compared with those of the Cav 2.3 WT. IBa through the WT (inactivating current (A1) = 1437 ± 154 nA (82 ± 1% of total current), τ = 111 ± 10 ms, and non-inactivating residual current (R) = 154 ± 15 nA (mean ± S.E.; n = 29)) and the quintuple mutant (A1 = 1790 ± 187 nA (84 ± 1% of total current), τ = 123 ± 4 ms, and R = 177 ± 16 nA (mean ± S.E.; n = 24)) channels showed similar mono-exponential inactivation. PMA potentiated the IBa through the Cav 2.3 WT channels significantly. In contrast, PMA-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents was significantly decreased in the oocytes expressing the quintuple mutant (Fig. 2A and Table I). Oocytes expressing the quintuple mutant were exposed to MCh to investigate the specificity of the PMA-selective sites. Surprisingly, MCh-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents was also significantly inhibited by the quintuple mutant (Fig. 2B and Table I). To narrow down the possible sites mediating the PMA and MCh responses, several mutants incorporating only some of the sites were constructed. Because the Ser/Thr residues of predicted PMA sites are located in the I-II linker (Thr-365, Ser-369), II-III linker (Thr-879), and the C terminus (Ser-1995, Ser-2011), three sets of Ala mutants comprising the I-II linker, II-III linker, and the C-terminal sites were constructed. PMA-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 current was inhibited by the I-II linker double mutant, T365A/S369A, not by the II-III linker mutant T879A or the C-terminal mutant S1995A/S2011A (Fig. 3A and Table I). Similarly, MCh-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 current was decreased by T365A/S369A and unaffected by T879A or S1995A/S2011A (Fig. 3B and Table I). To determine whether only one of the I-II linker sites was required, the single Ala mutations of Thr-365 and Ser-369 were constructed. Although T365A significantly inhibited the effect of PMA or MCh, S369A failed to modulate their responses (Fig. 4). Thus the inhibition of PMA or MCh response by the quintuple mutant was narrowed down to Thr-365 of the I-II linker. However, a contribution by the other sites (Ser-369, Thr-879, Ser-1995, and Ser-2011) is possible, because greater inhibition of PMA- or MCh-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents was observed with the quintuple mutant than with T365A (see Figs. 2 and 4, Table I). Hence, several mutants with or without Thr-365 were constructed to examine the contribution of additional sites in the action of PMA or MCh.Table ISummary of PMA or MCh effects on the Cav 2.3 WT or The numbers in parentheses indicate numbers of experiments. a, p < 0.001; b, p < 0.01 compared with 2.3 WT; t test.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Other Potential PKC Sites Contribute along with Thr-365 to the PMA- or MCh-induced Potentiation of Cav 2.3 Currents under Some Circumstances—To examine the role of the other potential PKC sites in PMA- or MCh-induced increase in the Cav 2.3 current, a quadruple mutant involving all of the additional sites was constructed. The Ala quadruple mutation including Ser-369, Thr-879, Ser-1995, and Ser-2011 failed to significantly modify the effect of PMA or MCh (Fig. 5). In consideration of the possibility that some of these other sites contribute only with Thr-365, several double and triple mutants including Thr-365 and the other selected PKC sites were constructed. All of the double mutants, viz. T365A/S369A, T365A/T879A, T365A/S1995A, and T365A/S2011A, decreased PMA-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 current compared with their controls. However, they failed to match the effect of the Ala quintuple mutant quantitatively (Table I). The triple mutants, viz. T365A/S369A/T879A, T365A/S369A/S1995A, T365A/S369A/S2011A, T365A/T879A/S1995A, T365A/T879A/S2011A, and T365A/S1995A/S2011A, also significantly inhibited the PMA response (Table I). The inhibition of the PMA response produced by one of the triple mutants, T365A/S369A/S1995A, was significantly greater than that of T365A and was equivalent to that of the Ala quintuple mutant (Fig. 6 and Table I). MCh-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents was also decreased in a similar manner by T365A/S369A/S1995A, as the inhibition of the MCh response by this triple mutant was significantly greater than that produced by T365A (Fig. 6 and Table I). Similarly, another triple mutant involving Thr-365 and the MCh-specific sites Ser-892 and Ser-1987 (1Kamatchi G. Franke R. Lynch III, C. Sando J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4102-4109Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar), T365A/S892A/S1987A, showed inhibition similar to that of the Ala quintuple mutant or the triple mutant T365A/S369A/S1995A. In contrast the effect of PMA with T365A/S892A/S1987A was similar to that of T365A (Fig. 6).Fig. 6Effect of PMA (A) (100 nm) or MCh (B) (1 μm) on the Cav 2.3 currents expressed by single, triple, or quintuple mutants of α1 2.3 subunit. The current was coexpressed in Xenopus oocytes with α1 2.3 WT or the α1 2.3 mutants with β1B and α2/δ subunits and muscarinic M1 receptors. The oocytes were incubated at 16 °C for 7–8 days and voltage-clamped using –80 and 0 mV as holding and test potentials, respectively. The bars represent the averaged peak IBa in the mutants. 2.3 WT represents the pooled parallel controls. The numbers in parentheses indicate numbers of experiments. a, p < 0.001; b, p < 0.01 compared with 2.3 WT. **, p < 0.001; *, p < 0.01; #, p < 0.02 compared with T365A. NS, not significant compared with T365A; t test.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Ser/Thr → Asp Substitution of the Predicted PMA Sites Substantiate the Primary Role Played by Thr-365 and the Supportive Action of Ser-369 and Ser-1995—The roles played by Thr-365, Ser-369, and Ser-1995 were analyzed further by mutating these Ser/Thr residues to Asp to mimic the negative charge of a phosphorylated residue. The IBa through T365D or 2.3 WT channels was analyzed in parallel. Compared with the 2.3 WT, IBa through T365D channels was significantly larger (Fig. 7, A–C). Coincident with this increase in the size of the basal current in T365D, the effect of PMA or MCh (Fig. 7D) was decreased significantly. To further analyze the mechanism of interaction between Thr-365 and the other potential PKC sites, we constructed a quintuple mutant in which Thr-365 was mutated to Asp and the other sites to Ala (T365D/S369A/T879A/S1995A/S2011A). The IBa through this Asp (one)/Ala (four) quintuple mutant was significantly larger compared with 2.3 WT analyzed in parallel (Fig. 8, A–C). The increase in the basal current in this Asp (one)/Ala (four) quintuple mutant was accompanied by a decrease in the PMA- or MCh-induced potentiation of Cav 2.3 currents of greater magnitude than that observed with just the T365D mutant (Fig. 8D). Because the inhibition produced by the triple mutant T365A/ S369A/S1995A matched the inhibition produced by the quintuple mutant T365A/S369A/T879A/S1995A/S2011A, the triple Asp mutant T365D/S369D/S1995D was constructed. The IBa through this Asp triple mutant was significantly greater compared with the current through 2.3 WT acquired and analyzed in parallel (Fig. 9, A–C). The increase in the IBa with the Asp triple mutant was accompanied by a decrease in the PMA or MCh response. Moreover, the decrease in PMA or MCh response observed with the Asp triple mutant was significantly more than that seen with T365D (Fig. 9D). PKC has been implicated in the regulation of various Cav channels on the basis of enhancement of current in response to treatment with PMA and agonists of some G-protein-coupled receptors (1Kamatchi G. Franke R. Lynch III, C. Sando J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4102-4109Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 5Stea A. Soong T.W. Snutch T.P. Neuron. 1995; 15: 929-940Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar) and by inhibition of the responses with some PKC inhibitors (9Kamatchi G. Tiwari S. Chan C. Chen D. Do S.-H. Durieux M. Lynch III, C. Brain Res. 2003; 968: 227-237Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). In previous work (1Kamatchi G. Franke R. Lynch III, C. Sando J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4102-4109Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar) we identified sites in the II-III linker of the α1 2.3 subunit that are required for the unique response of Cav 2.3 currents to MCh. Here we have identified sites in the α1 2.3 subunit that are required for the enhancement of Cav 2.3 currents by PMA and found that the most critical site is required for the response to MCh as well. Two sites in the I-II linker of α1 2.3 subunit (Thr-365 and Ser-369) that are homologous to those previously identified in the PMA-responsive α1 2.2 subunit (6Hamid J. Nelson D. Spaetgens R. Dubel S. Snutch T. Zamponi G. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6195-6202Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar) were targeted along with one site in the II-III linker (Thr-879) and two in the C terminus (Ser-1995 and Ser-2011) (Fig. 2). The most critical site was identified as Thr-365 in the I-II linker. T365A eliminated most of the response (Fig. 4), and Ala mutation of the other four sites was without effect (Fig. 5). A more complete loss of the response was obtained when Thr-365, as well as Ser-369 and Ser-1995, was mutated to Ala (Fig. 6), suggesting that the other sites may contribute to the effect but only if Thr-365 in the I-II linker is available. Mutation of Thr-365 to Asp to mimic the negative charge of a phosphorylated residue significantly increased the basal current when the rest of the channel was WT or when the other four sites were mutated to Ala and caused a corresponding decrease in the response to PMA (Figs. 7 and 8). These results support the possibility that the PMA response involves phosphorylation of Thr-365. The facts that the PMA response was more completely diminished when Thr-365 was mutated to Asp and the other four sites were mutated to Ala or when Ser-369 and Ser-1995 also were mutated to Asp are again consistent with a secondary role of these latter sites in generating the full PMA response. Because single amino acid mutations may affect the trafficking efficiency of assembled multi-subunit channels, the results obtained with the Asp mutations may be related to the altered surface expression levels. The fact that all of the relevant Asp mutants showed an increase in the basal current accompanied by a decrease in the response to PMA or MCh argues against altered expression as an explanation for the changes in the current. The observation that mutation of the primary Thr-365 site and the secondary Ser-369 and Ser-1995 sites caused similar loss of the MCh response (Figs. Fig. 2, Fig. 3, Fig. 4, Fig. 5, Fig. 6, Fig. 7) was surprising because the α1 2.2 subunit has comparable I-II linker sites (Thr-422 and Ser-425), and it responds only to PMA and not to MCh. However, combination of the I-II linker mutation T365A with Ala mutation of the previously identified MCh-selective sites in the II-III linker (Ser-892) and C terminus (Ser-1987) showed a more dramatic loss of the MCh response than of the PMA response (Fig. 6). Thus, the MCh response seems to require the Thr-365 in the I-II linker in common with the PMA response, but in addition it requires especially Ser-892 in the II-III linker as well as Ser-1987 in the C terminus. Collectively, these results may hint at possible ordering of putative phosphorylation events with the phosphorylation of Thr-365 required before the participation of other modulating sites, Ser-369 and Ser-1995 in the case of common PMA/MCh responses, or Ser-892 and Ser-1987 in the case of MCh-selective responses. Alternatively, phosphorylation at the secondary sites may occur but, in the absence of phosphorylation at Thr-365, cause no effect. The identification of common sites through which both MCh and PMA act suggests the involvement of common PKC isozymes activated by both stimuli. The identification of unique sites required for MCh action suggests that MCh may activate additional PKC isozymes (or other pathways) not activated by PMA. Because MCh activates phospholipid hydrolysis with the generation of both DAG and inositol triphosphate, which can release [Ca2+]i stores (10van Koppen C. Kaiser B. Pharmacol. Ther. 2003; 98: 197-220Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar), it would be expected to cause activation of Ca2+-dependent cPKCs as well as Ca2+-independent nPKCs. Some members of all three classes of PKC isozymes have been identified in Xenopus oocytes (11Johnson J. Capco D. Mech. Dev. 1997; 67: 215-226Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). PMA is a much more potent agonist at the DAG binding site of cPKCs and nPKCs, but because it does not lead directly to release of [Ca2+]i, it would not be expected to provide good activation of the Ca2+-dependent cPKCs. Thus we hypothesize that both PMA and MCh may activate nPKCs, which may phosphorylate the critical I-II linker Thr-365 site as well as some secondary sites required for common PMA and MCh enhancement of Cav 2.3 currents, but that only MCh may activate cPKCs, which may phosphorylate the critical II-III linker site Ser-892 and others that selectively regulate the MCh response. The mechanisms by which phosphorylation affects channel conductance are yet to be established. Hall et al. (12Hall K.E. Browning M.D. Dudek E.M. Macdonald R.L. J. Neurosci. 1995; 15: 6069-6076Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) have suggested an increase in channel conductance or channel open time in response to PKC activation. Based on single channel studies, others have postulated that Cav channels may exist in different states that are more or less excitable (13Boland L.M. Bean B.P. J. Neurosci. 1993; 13: 516-533Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14Delcour A.H. Tsien R.W. Science. 1993; 259: 980-984Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar) and that the action of PKC is to switch the channel to a more easily excited state (15Yang J. Tsien R.W. Neuron. 1993; 10: 127-136Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (152) Google Scholar). The localization of PMA- and MCh-selective sites in the I-II and II-III linkers is significant because these linkers represent regions of alternative splicing and binding sites for the β subunit and receptor proteins required for the release of neurotransmitters (2Walker D. De Waard M. Trends Neurosci. 1998; 21: 148-154Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (314) Google Scholar, 16Rettig J. Sheng Z-H. Kim D.K. Hodson C.D. Snutch T.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 7363-7368Crossref PubMed Scopus (259) Google Scholar, 17Sheng Z-H. Rettig J. Cook T. Catterall W. Nature. 1996; 379: 451-454Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). The understanding of the susceptibility of the PKC phosphorylation sites to various PKC isozymes may help to explain the basis for the differential responses of Cav channels to various agonists, neurotransmitters, and hormones. Bonner (Laboratory of Cell Biology, National Institute of Mental Health, Bethesda, MD) for the muscarinic M1 receptor clone.

SPEC1 and SPEC2 are structurally similar Cdc42-binding proteins of 79 and 84 amino acid residues, respectively. We investigated the role of SPEC2 in T cell function due to its high mRNA expression in lymphocytes. Western blot analysis revealed abundant SPEC2 protein in lymphocytes, which in glutathione S-transferase-capture experiments specifically interacted with only GTP-bound Cdc42. Immunofluorescence experiments revealed that the SPEC2 protein was diffusely localized in the cytoplasm and at the cell membrane in unstimulated Jurkat T cells and Raji B cells. Recruitment of SPEC2 within Jurkat T cells to the antigen-presenting cell interface occurred following incubation with staphylococcal enterotoxin E superantigen-loaded B cells and colocalized there with F-actin and Cdc42. T cell receptor (TCR) activation studies using anti-CD3 antibody-coated polystyrene beads showed that SPEC2 was recruited to the site of bead contact, which was not observed with anti-major histocompatibility complex antibody-coated beads. Accumulation of SPEC2 following TCR engagement occurred as early as 5 min, before obvious F-actin accumulation. Biochemical studies with Jurkat T cells demonstrated that N-terminal cysteine residues in SPEC2 were palmitoylated. Overexpression studies of the related SPEC1 showed that it also was recruited to the activated TCR. Mutational analysis revealed that localization of SPEC1 to the TCR required two N-terminal cysteine residues. Furthermore, a SPEC1 Cdc42 Rac-interacting binding mutant, containing an intact N terminus but defective in Cdc42 binding, completely blocked F-actin accumulation at the activated TCR. Taken together these results suggest that SPECs may play important roles in Cdc42-mediated F-actin accumulation at the immunological synapse.
